sen.j: 四道将軍（しどうしょうぐん）は、『日本書紀』に登場する皇族（王族）の将軍で、大彦命（おおびこのみこと）、武渟川別（たけぬなかわわけのみこと）、吉備津彦命（きびつひこのみこと）、丹波道主命（たんばみちぬしのみこと）の4人を指す。
sen.e: The term "Shido-shogun" means four imperial (royal) generals who appeared in the Nihon Shoki (the Chronicle of Japan,) namely Obiko no mikoto, Takenunakawa wake no mikoto, Kibitsuhiko no mikoto and tanbamichi nushi no mikoto.

The term "Shido-shogun" means four imperial (royal) generals who appeared in the Nihon Shoki (the Chronicle of Japan,) namely Obiko no mikoto, Takenunakawa wake no mikoto, Kibitsuhiko no mikoto and tanbamichi nushi no mikoto.

The term "Shido-shogun" refers to four imperial (royal) generals who appeared in the Nihon Shoki (the Chronicle of Japan), namely Obiko no mikoto, Takenunakawa wake no mikoto, Kibitsuhiko no mikoto and tanbamichi nushi no mikoto.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』によると、崇神天皇10年（紀元前88年？）にそれぞれ、北陸、東海、西道、丹波に派遣された。
sen.e: According to the "Nihon Shoki," each of these generals was dispatched to Kuga no michi (Hokuriku circuit,) Umitsu michi (Tokai circuit,) Nishi no michi (Sanyo circuit) and Tanba michi (Sanin circuit), in the 10th year of Emperor Sujin's reign (87 B.C. ?)
sen.cmt: 「北陸」「東海」「西道」「丹波」のそれぞれを日本書紀流の読み方にし、直後の（ ）内にその意味を記しました。
sen.e: According to the "Nihon Shoki," each of these generals was dispatched to Kuga no michi (Hokuriku circuit,) Umitsu michi (Tokai circuit,) Nishi no michi (Sanyo circuit) and Tanba michi (Sanin circuit), in the 10th year of Emperor Sujin's reign (87 B.C. ?)

According to the "Nihon Shoki," each of these generals was dispatched to Kuga no michi (Hokuriku circuit), Umitsu michi (Tokai circuit), Nishi no michi (Sanyo circuit) and Tanba michi (Sanin circuit), in the 10th year of Emperor Sujin's reign (88 B.C. ?)

sen.j: 教えを受けない者があれば兵を挙げて伐つようにと将軍の印綬を授けられ、翌崇神天皇11年（紀元前87年？）地方の敵を帰順させて凱旋したとされている。
sen.e: They were appointed as the generals to use armed forces against and defeat those who would not accept Emperor's precepts, and it was reportedly in the next year, the 11th year of Emperor Sujin's reign (87 B.C. ?) that these generals returned in triumph after subdueing their local rebels.
sen.cmt: 「教え」を「天皇の教え」と解釈し「Emperor's precepts」と訳しました。
sen.e: They were appointed as the generals to use armed forces against and defeat those who would not accept Emperor's precepts, and it was reportedly in the following year, the 11th year of Emperor Sujin's reign (87 B.C. ?) that these generals returned in triumph after subdueing their local rebels.

They were appointed as generals to use armed force against and defeat those who would not accept the Emperor's precepts, and it was reportedly in the following year, the 11th year of Emperor Sujin's reign (87 B.C. ?) that these generals returned in triumph after subduing the local rebels.
sen.cmt: スペース調整スペルを修正

sen.j: （実際には4世紀初めのことと思われる）
sen.e: (This is, however, believed to have actually happened at around the beginning of fourth century).
(This is, however, believed to have actually happened at around the beginning of fourth century).
(This is, however, believed to have actually happened at around the beginning of the fourth century.)

sen.j: なお『古事記』では、4人をそれぞれ個別に記載した記事は存在するが、一括して取り扱ってはおらず、四道将軍の呼称も記載されていない。
sen.e: For reference's sake, in the "Kojiki" (the "Record of Anscient Matters,") the generals were not collectively described and no designation of Shido-shogun was used although description of each general of the four appeared individually in some articles.

For reference's sake, in the "Kojiki" (the "Record of Anscient Matters,") the generals were not collectively described and no designation of Shido-shogun was used although description of each general of the four appeared individually in some articles.

For reference's sake, in the "Kojiki" (the Record of Ancient Matters), the generals were not collectively described and no designation of Shido-shogun was used although a description of each of the four generals appeared individually in some articles.
sen.cmt: コンマ移動"削除スペルを修正

sen.j: また、吉備津彦命の名前もない。
sen.e: Also, there was no name of Kibitsuhiko no mikoto written in the Kojiki.
Also, there was no name of Kibitsuhiko no mikoto written in the Kojiki.
Also, there was no name of Kibitsuhiko no mikoto written in the Kojiki.

sen.j: （別名は記載されている。）
sen.e: (Instead, his alias name was described there)
(Instead, his alias name was described there)
(Instead, his alias name was described there)

sen.j: また、『常陸国風土記』では武渟川別が、『丹後国風土記』では丹波道主命の父である彦坐王が記述されている。
sen.e: Takenunakawa wake no mikoto was also written about in the "Hitachi no kuni fudoki" ("the topography of Hitachi Province,") as well as Hikoimasu no miko, father of Tanbamichi nushi no mikoto, was referred to in "Tango no kuni fudoki" ("the topography of Tango Province.")
sen.cmt: 用語登録では、「丹後国風土記」は「the ｒecords of Tango Province」となっております。
sen.e: Takenunakawa wake no mikoto was also written about in the "Hitachi no kuni fudoki" ("the topography of Hitachi Province,") as well as Hikoimasu no miko, father of Tanbamichi nushi no mikoto, was referred to in "Tango no kuni fudoki" ("the topography of Tango Province.")

Takenunakawa wake no mikoto was also written about in the "Hitachi no kuni fudoki" (the topography of Hitachi Province), as well as Hikoimasu no miko, father of Tanbamichi nushi no mikoto, who was referred to in "Tango no kuni fudoki" (the topography of Tango Province).
sen.cmt: コンマ・ピリオド移動"削除

sen.j: 四道将軍の説話は単なる神話ではなく、豊城入彦命の派遣やヤマトタケル伝説などとも関連する王族による国家平定説話の一部であり、初期ヤマト王権による支配権が地方へ伸展する様子を示唆しているとする見解がある。
sen.e: According to one explanation, the story of Shido-shogun is not merely a myth but a part of a narrative of conquest of a country by members of the royal family associated with the dispatch of Toyokiirihikono-mikoto and the legend of Yamato Takeru, thus suggesting how the royal power of the early Yamato dynasty had expanded its hegemony.

According to one explanation, the story of Shido-shogun is not merely a myth but a part of a narrative of conquest of a country by members of the royal family associated with the dispatch of Toyokiirihikono-mikoto and the legend of Yamato Takeru, thus suggesting how the royal power of the early Yamato dynasty had expanded its hegemony.

According to one explanation, the story of Shido-shogun is not merely a myth but a part of a narrative of conquest of a country by members of the royal family associated with the dispatch of Toyokiirihikono-mikoto and the legend of Yamato Takeru, thus suggesting how the royal power of the early Yamato dynasty had expanded its hegemony.

sen.j: 事実その平定ルートは、四世紀の前方後円墳の伝播地域とほぼ重なっている。
sen.e: In fact, their route conquest almost overlaps regions where a number of large keyhole-shaped tomb mounds were propagated in the fourth century,.
In fact, their route conquest almost overlaps regions where a number of large keyhole-shaped tomb mounds were propagated in the fourth century,.
In fact, their route conquest almost overlaps regions where a number of large keyhole-shaped tomb mounds were propagated in the fourth century,.

sen.j: 大彦命は、孝元天皇の第1皇子で、母は皇后・鬱色謎命（うつしこめのみこと）。
sen.e: Obiko no mikoto was born as the first prince of Emperor and Empress Utsushikome no mikoto.
Obiko no mikoto was born as the first prince of Emperor and Empress Utsushikome no mikoto.
Obiko no mikoto was born as the first prince of Emperor Kogen and Empress Utsushikome no mikoto.

sen.j: 開化天皇の同母兄で、娘は崇神天皇皇后の御間城姫命（みまきひめのみこと）、垂仁天皇の外祖父に当たる。
sen.e: He was an elder brother-uterne of Emperor Kaika and a maternal grandfather of Emperor Suinin, since his daughter Mimakihime no mikoto was an empress consort of Emperor Sujin.
He was an elder brother-uterne of Emperor Kaika and a maternal grandfather of Emperor Suinin, since his daughter Mimakihime no mikoto was an empress consort of Emperor Sujin.
He was an elder maternal-brother of Emperor Kaika and a maternal grandfather of Emperor Suinin, since his daughter Mimakihime no mikoto was an empress consort of Emperor Sujin.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 舟津神社（福井県鯖江市）、敢國神社（三重県伊賀市）、伊佐須美神社（福島県会津美里町）、古四王神社（秋田県秋田市）等に祀られている。
sen.e: Ohiko no mikoto is enshrined in Funatsu-jinja shrine (Sabae City, Fukui Prefecture,) Aekuni-jinja shrine (Iga City, Mie Prefecture,) Isasumi-jinja shrine (Aizu Misato-machi Town, Fukushima Prefecture,) Koshio-jinja shrine (Akita City, Akita Prefecture) and so on.

Ohiko no mikoto is enshrined in Funatsu-jinja shrine (Sabae City, Fukui Prefecture,) Aekuni-jinja shrine (Iga City, Mie Prefecture,) Isasumi-jinja shrine (Aizu Misato-machi Town, Fukushima Prefecture,) Koshio-jinja shrine (Akita City, Akita Prefecture) and so on.

Ohiko no mikoto is enshrined in Funatsu-jinja Shrine (Sabae City, Fukui Prefecture), Aekuni-jinja Shrine (Iga City, Mie Prefecture), Isasumi-jinja Shrine (Aizu Misato-machi-cho, Fukushima Prefecture), Koshio-jinja Shrine (Akita City, Akita Prefecture) and other Shrines.

sen.j: 武渟川別は、大彦命の子。
sen.e: Takenunakawa wake no mikoto was a son of Obiko no mikoto.
Takenunakawa wake no mikoto was a son of Obiko no mikoto.

sen.j: 阿倍氏等の祖と伝えられる。
sen.e: He was reportedly a founder of Abe and other clans.

sen.j: 津神社（岐阜県岐阜市）、健田須賀神社（茨城県結城市）等に祀られている。
sen.e: Takenunakawa wake no mikoto is enshrined in Tsu-jinja shrine (Gufu City, Gifu Prefecture), Takedasuga-jinja shrine (Yuki City, Ibaraki Prefecture) and so on.

sen.j: また『古事記』によれば、北陸道を平定した大彦命と、東海道を平定した武渟川別が合流した場所が会津であるとされている。
sen.e: According to "Kojiki," Aizu was the place where Obiko no mikoto and Takenunakawa wake no mikoto joined together after having conquered Kuga no michi (Hokuriku region) and Umitsu michi (Tokai region) respectively.

According to "Kojiki," Aizu was the place where Obiko no mikoto and Takenunakawa wake no mikoto joined together after having conquered Kuga no michi (Hokuriku region) and Umitsu michi (Tokai region) respectively.

sen.j: （会津の地名由来説話）。
sen.e: (A tale about the origin of the place-name of Aizu)
(A tale about the origin of the place-name of Aizu)

sen.j: このときの両者の行軍経路を阿賀野川（大彦命）と鬼怒川（武渟川別）と推察する見解が哲学者の中路正恒から出されている。
sen.e: Philosopher Masatsune NAKAJI proposed the view that Obiko no mikoto had marched along the Agano-gawa river and Takenunakawa wake no mikoto along the Kinu-gawa river.
Philosopher Masatsune NAKAJI proposed the view that Obiko no mikoto had marched along the Agano-gawa river and Takenunakawa wake no mikoto along the Kinu-gawa river.
Philosopher Masatsune NAKAJI proposed the view that Obiko no mikoto had marched along the Agano-gawa river and Takenunakawa wake no mikoto along the Kinu-gawa river.

sen.j: 吉備津彦は、孝霊天皇の皇子で、母は倭国香媛（やまとのくにかひめ）。
sen.e: Kibitsuhiko was born as a prince of Emperor Korei and Empress Yamato no kuni kahime.
Kibitsuhiko was born as a prince of Emperor Korei and Empress Yamato no kuni kahime.
Kibitsuhiko was born as a prince of Emperor Korei and Empress Yamato no kuni kahime.

sen.j: 別名は五十狭芹彦（いさせりひこ）。
sen.e: His alias was Isaserihiko.
His alias was Isaserihiko.
His alias was Isaserihiko.

sen.j: 吉備国を平定したために吉備津彦を名乗ったと考えられているが、古事記には吉備津彦の名は出てこない。
sen.e: He is believed to have called himself Kibitsuhiko as he had suppressed Kibi Province, but there was no such name written in the Kojiki.
He is believed to have called himself Kibitsuhiko as he had suppressed Kibi Province, but there was no such name written in the Kojiki.
He is believed to have called himself Kibitsuhiko as he had suppressed Kibi Province, but there was no such name written in the Kojiki.

sen.j: 桃太郎のモデルの一つであったとも言われている。
sen.e: It is also said to have been one of the models of Momotaro (literally, a peach boy,) a hero of a fairy tale.
It is also said to have been one of the models of Momotaro (literally, a peach boy,) a hero of a fairy tale.
It is also said to have been one of the models of Momotaro (literally, a peach boy), a hero of a fairy tale.

sen.j: 吉備津神社 (岡山市)（岡山県岡山市）、田村神社 (高松市)（香川県高松市）等に祀られている。
sen.e: Kibitsuhiko no mikoto is enshrined in Kibitsu-jinja shrine (Okayama City) (Okayama City, Okayama Prefecture,) Tamura-jinja shrine (Takamatsu City) (Takamatsu City, Kagawa Prefecture) and so on.

sen.cmt: (Okayama City)(Takamatsu City) サイトにはないので、削除shrine語頭大文字

sen.j: 丹波道主命は、古事記によると開化天皇の子、彦坐王の子。
sen.e: According to the Kojiki, Tanbamichi nushi no mikoto was a son of Hikoimasu no miko, a prince of Emperor Kaika.
According to the Kojiki, Tanbamichi nushi no mikoto was a son of Hikoimasu no miko, a prince of Emperor Kaika.
According to the Kojiki, Tanbamichi nushi no mikoto was a son of Hikoimasu no miko, a prince of Emperor Kaika.

sen.j: なお、古事記では彦坐王が丹波に派遣されたとある。
sen.e: In addition, according to the Kojiki, Hikoimasu no miko was dispatched to Tanba.
In addition, according to the Kojiki, Hikoimasu no miko was dispatched to Tanba.
In addition, according to the Kojiki, Hikoimasu no miko was dispatched to Tanba.

sen.j: 母は息長水依比売娘（おきながのみずよりひめ）。
sen.e: His mother was Okinaga no mizuyori hime.
His mother was Okinaga no mizuyori hime.
His mother was Okinaga no mizuyori hime.

sen.j: 娘は垂仁天皇皇后の日葉酢媛命（ひばすひめ）。
sen.e: His daughter was Hibasu hime, an empress consort of Emperor Suinin.
His daughter was Hibasu hime, an empress consort of Emperor Suinin.
His daughter was Hibasu hime, an empress consort of Emperor Suinin.

sen.j: 景行天皇の外祖父に当たる。
sen.e: He is a maternal grandfather of Emperor Keiko.
He was the maternal grandfather of Emperor Keiko.
He was the maternal grandfather of Emperor Keiko.

sen.j: 神谷神社（京都府京丹後市）等に祀られている。
sen.e: Tanbamichi nushi no mikoto is enshrined in Kamitani-jinja shrine (Kyotango City, Kyoto Prefecture) and so on.
Tanbamichi nushi no mikoto is enshrined in Kamitani-jinja shrine (Kyotango City, Kyoto Prefecture) and so on.
Tanbamichi nushi no mikoto is enshrined in Kamitani-jinja Shrine (Kyotango City, Kyoto Prefecture) and so on.

sen.j: 大彦命に関しては、埼玉県の稲荷山古墳から発掘された金錯銘鉄剣に見える乎獲居臣（ヲワケの臣）の上祖・意冨比垝（オホビコ、オホヒコ）と同一人である可能性が高いとする見解が有力である。
sen.e: Regarging Obiko no mikoto, the most convincing explanation is that he was most probably identical with Ohobiko or Ohohiko, a forefather of Owake no omi which name was inscribed on Kinsakumei-tekken (an iron sword with gold-inlaid inscriptions) excavated at the Inariyama kofun (an ancient tomb at Mt. Inariyama) in Saitama Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 登録用語では、「稲荷山古墳」は「Inariyam-kofun tumulus」となっています。
sen.e: Regarding Obiko no mikoto, the most convincing explanation is that he was most probably identical to Ohobiko or Ohohiko, a forefather of Owake no omi whose name was inscribed on Kinsakumei-tekken (an iron sword with gold-inlaid inscriptions) excavated at the Inariyama kofun (an ancient tomb at Mt. Inariyama) in Saitama Prefecture.

Regarding Obiko no mikoto, the most convincing explanation is that he was most probably identical to Ohobiko or Ohohiko, a forefather of Owake no omi whose name was inscribed on Kinsakumei-tekken (an iron sword with gold-inlaid inscriptions) excavated at the Inariyama kofun (an ancient tomb at Mt. Inariyama) in Saitama Prefecture.

sen.j: このことから、四道将軍が創作された神話ではなく、実際に伝承された祖先伝説を元に構成されたことを示しているとも考えられている。
sen.e: This explanation may show that the tales of Shido-shogun are not fictional but composed of ancestral legends which were actually transferred by forebears.
This explanation may show that the tales of Shido-shogun are not fictional but composed of ancestral legends which were actually transferred by forebears.
This explanation may show that the tales of Shido-shogun are not fictional but composed of ancestral legends which were actually transferred by the forebears.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 崇神天皇陵に比定されている行燈山古墳（墳丘全長約242m、後円部直径約158m、後円部高さ約23m）と吉備津彦命の陵墓参考地（大吉備津彦命墓）である中山茶臼山古墳（墳丘全長約120m、後円部直径約80ｍ、後円部高さ約12ｍ）はサイズがほぼ2対1の相似形であることが指摘されている。
sen.e: It is pointed out that Andon-yama kofun (an ancient tomb at Mt. Andonyama) which is identified with the Mausoleum of Emperor Sujin (with total length of about 242m, and diameter of about 158m and height of about 23m both of the rounded part) is similar in shape to the referable mausoleum of Kibitsuhiko no mikoto (the Tomb of Great Kibitsuhiko no mikoto) which is called Nakayama Chausuyama kofun (an ancient tomb at Mt. Nakayama Chausuyama) (with total length of about 120m and diameter of about 80m and height of about 12m both of the rounded part,) the ratio of sizes of which is about two to one.
sen.cmt: 登録用語では、「行燈山古墳」は「Andon-yama kofun (Andon-yama tumulus)」となっています。
sen.e: It is pointed out that Andon-yama kofun (an ancient tomb at Mt. Andonyama) which is identified with the Mausoleum of Emperor Sujin (with total length of about 242m, and diameter of about 158m and height of about 23m both of the rounded part) is similar in shape to the referable mausoleum of Kibitsuhiko no mikoto (the Tomb of Great Kibitsuhiko no mikoto) which is called Nakayama Chausuyama kofun (an ancient tomb at Mt. Nakayama Chausuyama) (with total length of about 120m and diameter of about 80m and height of about 12m both of the rounded part,) the ratio of sizes of which is about two to one.

It is pointed out that Andon-yama kofun (an ancient tomb at Mt. Andonyama) which is identified with the Mausoleum of Emperor Sujin (having a total length of about 242 m, and the rounded part having a diameter of about 158 m and height of about 23 m) is similar in shape to the referential mausoleum of Kibitsuhiko no mikoto (the Tomb of Great Kibitsuhiko no mikoto) which is called Nakayama Chausuyama kofun (an ancient tomb at Mt. Nakayama Chausuyama) (having a total length of about 120 m and the rounded part having a diameter of about 80 m and height of about 12 m), the ratio of which is about two to one.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 前田晴人は四道将軍の神話自体は史実とは認めないものの、ここに描かれた「四道」を五畿七道成立以前のヤマト王権の地域区分であったとし、四道将軍はその成立を説明するために創作された説話であるとする説を唱えている。
sen.e: Haruto MAEDA, a contemporary historian, would not acknowledge historicity of the Shido-shogun stories, but is advocating that "shido"meant regional division designed by Yamato sovereignty before establishing goki-shichido system (geological classification composed of five provinces in the capital region and seven circuits outside of it,) and that the tales of Shido-shogun were the fictions created to explain the process of establishing the goki-shichido system.

Haruto MAEDA, a contemporary historian, would not acknowledge historicity of the Shido-shogun stories, but is advocating that "shido"meant regional division designed by Yamato sovereignty before establishing goki-shichido system (geological classification composed of five provinces in the capital region and seven circuits outside of it,) and that the tales of Shido-shogun were the fictions created to explain the process of establishing the goki-shichido system.

Haruto MAEDA, a contemporary historian, would not acknowledge the historical authenticity of the Shido-shogun stories, and instead advocates that 'shido' referred to the regional division designed by Yamato sovereignty before establishing the goki-shichido system (a geological classification composed of five provinces in the capital region and seven circuits outside), and that the tales of Shido-shogun were fictions created to explain the process of establishing the goki-shichido system.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。
